articles.title: Ciara Sterbenz
articles.contents:
Hello!



 Email: cster@g.ucla.edu  I am currently a Ph.D Candidate
at the University of California, Los Angeles and a US-Asia Grand
Strategy Predoctoral Fellow at The Korean Studies Institute at
University of Southern California. I’m grateful to be under the
advisement of Prof Chad Hazlett.  Name Pronunciation: “Kee-ruh”
(Irish spellings are bonkers)

Research
My research explores the domestic drivers of aggressive foreign
policy, paying particular attention to executive appeals to nationalism
and historical memory centering international rivalry. I focus inquiry
on East Asia primarily among Japan, South Korea, and China.
Additionally, I am also interested in political methodology and in
separate projects explore applications of LLMs in political research,
reducing user-specification sensitivity in survey weighting and causal
inference approaches to observational data broadly speaking.
Teaching
At UCLA, I have twice taught a specialized upper-division seminar
“Politics of East Asia: Unique Puzzles in International Relations” as
well as our department’s required statistics class for all majors
“Introduction to Data Analysis.” As a TA, I have also taught in
Introduction to IR, as well as in graduate-level methodology courses
including MLE, Causal Inference, and Experimental Design. I have also
served as our department “Math Maven” assisting fellow graduate students
on any problems related to methodology in their research or coursework
for several years and additionally taught the “Math Camp” review crash
course for incoming first year graduate students.
CV
